title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
Fed officials are set to accelerate deliberations at their meeting next week over how to scale back their easy-money policies amid a stronger U.S. economic recovery than they anticipated six months ago.

---

Intel's CEO sees the global semiconductor shortage potentially stretching into 2023, adding a leading industry voice to the growing view that the chip-supply disruptions won't wane soon.

---

Continued strong demand pushed the median U.S. home price to a record in June, though the national house-buying frenzy cooled slightly as supply ticked higher.

---

Bitcoin's steep selloff is undercutting the argument made by the digital currency's proponents that it is an inflation hedge.

---

Throngs of vacation travelers and an infusion of government aid have restored Southwest, American and Delta to profitability.

---

Snap continued its string of strong quarterly user and revenue growth, with its daily active user figure reaching 293 million in the latest quarter.

---

U.S. stocks rose, with the S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq gaining 0.2%, 0.1% and 0.4%, respectively.

---

Federal prosecutors said utility FirstEnergy agreed to pay $230 million to resolve charges that it was involved in an Ohio bribery scheme.

---

Mercedes-Benz said it is gearing up to go all-electric by the end of the decade, accelerating a transition to plug-in cars.
